statement.tex: %text Find the vector equation of the plane passing through three points with position vectors $\vector{1}{1}{-2}$, $\vector{2}{-1}{1}$ and $\vector{1}{2}{1}$. Also find the coordinates of the point of interection of this plane and the line $\ora{r}=\vector{3}{-1}{-1}+\lambda(\vector{2}{-2}{1})$. %

step.context: %text If the position vectors of the three coplanar points are $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{-2}$, $\ora{b}=\vector{2}{-1}{1}$, and $\ora{c}=\vector{1}{2}{1}$. Would the following represent a normal $\ora{n}$ to the plane? %
step.reason: %text Since $\ora{a}-\ora{b}$ and $\ora{a}-\ora{c}$ are vectors that lie in the plane, their cross-product has to be a vector perpendicular to the plane's surface. Note: There are two vectors normal to the plane. One going into the plane and one coming out. It doesn't matter which we use. %

step.context: \text{If }\begin{align} \ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{-2} \\ \ora{b}=\vector{2}{-1}{1} \\ \ora{c}=\vector{1}{2}{1} \end{align} \\ %text and $\ora{n}=(\ora{a}-\ora{b})\times (\ora{a}-\ora{c})$, is this the correct value of $\ora{n}$? %

%text If $\ora{r}$ is a position vector of any point on the plane, $\ora{n}=\vector{-9}{-3}{1}$ is the normal to the plane and $\ora{a}=\vector{1}{1}{-2}$ is a point on the plane, then does the following equation represent the plane? %
step.reason: %text If $\ora{r}$ and $\ora{a}$ are points on the surface of the plane and $\ora{n}$ is normal to the plane then the equation of the plane would be given by, % \begin{align} &(\ora{r}-\ora{a})\cdot\ora{n}=0 \\ \implies &\ora{r}\cdot\ora{n}-\ora{a}\cdot\ora{n}=0 \\ \implies &\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{-9}{-3}{1})- \\ &\qquad (\vector{1}{1}{-2})\cdot(\vector{-9}{-3}{1})=0 \\ \implies &\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{-9}{-3}{1})-(-14)=0 \\ \implies &\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{-9}{-3}{1})=-14 \\ \implies &\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{9}{3}{-1})=14 \end{align}

step.context: %text Plane: $\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{9}{3}{-1})=14$ Line: $\ora{r}=3 \vector{1}{-1}{-1}+\lambda(\vector{2}{-2}{1})$ If $\ora{r}$ lies on both the line and plane shown above, could this be its value? %
step.reason: %text Plane: $\ora{r}\cdot(\vector{9}{3}{-1})=14$ Line: $\ora{r}=\vector{3}{-1}{-1}+\lambda(\vector{2}{-2}{1})$ We need to find $\lambda$ such that $\ora{r}$ satisfies both equation, therefore, % \begin{align} &{\small (\vector{3}{-1}{-1}+\lambda(\vector{2}{-2}{1}))\cdot (\vector{9}{3}{-1})=14} \\ & {\small (\vector{3}{-1}{-1})\cdot (\vector{9}{3}{-1})+} \\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\small{\lambda(\vector{2}{-2}{1})\cdot (\vector{9}{3}{-1})=14} \\ &{\small(27-3+1)+\lambda(18-6-1)=14} \\ &\implies\lambda=-1 \end{align} \\ %text Substituting $\lambda=-1$ back in the equation of the line we get, % \begin{align} \therefore &\ora{r}=\vector{3}{-1}{-1}+\lambda(\vector{2}{-2}{1}) \\ \implies &\ora{r}=\vector{3}{-1}{-1}-\vector{2}{-2}{1} \\ \implies &{\bf\ora{r}=\vector{1}{1}{-2}} \end{align}
